course.description: Introduces machine learning based trading strategies. Topics: Information processing, probabilistic analysis, portfolio construction, generation of market orders, KNN, random forests.

textbooks.name: Python for Finance: Mastering Data-Driven Finance, 2nd Edition
What Hedge Funds Really Do: An Introduction to Portfolio Management

course.name: Machine Learning for Trading

reviews.body:
The reason I rate it a 2 is because despite some good learning points, the grading is terrible. Grading to me is very important for work reimbursements. 

Firstly, the graders take weeks to get back because there are too many students. Maybe reduce the student count or get more TAs? Why should students wait to find their grades out after going more than halfway into the course?

Second, I lost a huge amount of my marks to not following their guidelines correctly. My fault based on a confusion which I should have clarified. But if I got my marks earlier, I would have made sure I didn't make similar mistakes on future assignments or exam... 

Honestly felt like a bachelors course putting heavy focus on deducting marks through non technical means, to lower the class average. 

Overall, I loved the course material but was not a fan of the way it was managed. I would probably take the course again because the content was worth it, but would have loved the course if it was managed better.
Learn 1+1=2, homework is 1+1=?, and when you put 2 into the answer, it gives you zero for grading, since the correct answer is 2,000E-3

When to take:
I took this course in the Summer and I believe that is the mistake I made. Every weekend you have a project which makes it very difficult with work, so will highly recommend taking this course during either Spring or Fall.

Assignment and Lectures:
The course content is easier and a very good introduction to someone who has no/less financial knowledge so worked great for me. 
The assignments are straightforward but do take time to understand or sometimes make it work in the environment so I will highly recommend putting enough time there. 

READ THE REQUIREMENTS PROPERLY! I made the stupid mistake of not reading the requirement properly for one assignment and lost 20 points. Since the assignments are easy, these requirements matter a lot. 

Most time consuming assignments are assignment 3 and 8 so start early for these.

 Quizzes: 
The questions are confusing which I think is on purpose to ensure that you understood the concept and might make you lose points, since this course has a pre-defined grade structure, I will recommend putting time for lectures properly.

Staff:
Super helpful staff and TAs, great response time and provides great resources. In case of any doubt, post a question and they will respond lighting fast. Not exaggerating, they have done that.

Overall I will recommend this to anyone who has less financial knowledge and would try to experiment with this domain.

Overall, it's not a bad class. Not as much programming as classes like AOS and HPC, was less of a challenge than those classes. But still, it's well run

A lot of your grade comes from projects which have super long and specific requirements. The hardest part on the projects isn't the actual dev work, just reading the requirements and getting them all in your head at once (kind of like HPCA in this respect)

My favorite part about this class was the more finance-oriented part. Personally, I had a lot of blind spots going into this class (e.g. didn't know what hedge funds are or what options trading is). It helped cover those blind spots

I would totally be into taking some hypothetical course with Professor Balch that's 100% about finance

This was my 3rd course in the program (after AI4R that I loved and KBAI that I hated). The course was a mixed bag for me but overall I'm not regretting taking it (unlike KBAI that has no right to exist).
I work in finance and hence was not looking to learn much on the "trading" side of the course (which I think was a bit rudimentary). My goal was to have an intro to ML. With that, I think this course suited my goals, albeit requiring more work than was necessary for that.
I think I gained some basic intuition on the supervised learning (regressions, decision/random trees, ensemble methods) and reinforcement learning (Q learning with or w/o dyna). On top of that, I learned how to use Python (scipy) optimizer and (my favorite) how to vectorize in pandas and numpy - that really speeds things up while making the code neat at the same time.  
On the negative side:
1. Excessive amount of additional reading, most of which is useless (e.g. Handbook of AI and Big Data Applications in Investments - the book describes some use cases but it really does not teach you anything. Yet, the chapters are quite lengthy and takes a lot of time to read)
2. Projects are quite intense, especially for the Summer. Project 6 (on technical indicators) took me long time despite having a lower weight. Obviously projects 3 and especially 8 were very time consuming, it was unreasonable to give only 1 week to complete them.
3. Exams - it was not clear at all what these exams were supposed to assess. Very strange questions formulated using un-human English. 
4. Not a deal breaker, but some of the lectures are of a very poor quality. I really struggled to hear or see something on some of the videos.

I'm not sure how or why ML4T exists in this program. It feels like an intro level undergrad course. The only reason you should take ML4T is if you want easy credits or have never taken a programming class before. 

The course content is **very** outdated and extremely easy if you're decent at coding. Additionally, the Joyner style reports hold your hand to such a degree it's actually difficult to lose points as long as you're referencing the rubric when you write them.

Avoid this class if your goal is to learn. You'll gain more knowledge and achieve better trading results by watching a few YouTube tutorials that cover modern trading methods.

Background: Engineering undergrad with no formal CS background and not much Python experience. 2nd class in OMSCS. This class really taught me how to use Python for some pretty cool projects and is a great introduction to Machine Learning. Some of the projects are more difficult than others and are weighted appropriately. The concepts taught are very interested, especially those are actively invest and you learn a lot of important information from the financial side.

 I recommend trying to get ahead as all of the projects and lectures are posted, especially if you have travel plans as during the summer semester there was a project due every Sunday.

This was my first course in OMSCS,  and I liked it. I haven't programmed in Python before the course so it took me a while to pick it up. I Took this during the summer so there were weekly assignments, the assignments were pretty straight forward but it takes some time to write the report associated to them covering all the rubrics.  All the instructions were very detailed and clear and every time I had doubts about the instructions all of them were already answered in the Ed discussion forum. Most of the questions from the exam come from the obligatory readings and not from the lectures.

Overall I am pleased with the knowledge I gained taking this course, and I believe that the projects built well toward the "capstone" project 8. 

However, my biggest criticism of this course is the (unnecessarily) long project instructions with (imbalanced) penalties in their grading rubrics.

This produced in me a frustration with how difficult it was to glean specific project requirements out of these long-winded project specs and how harsh a penalty for missing just one of those requirements might have on your project grade. Honestly, I feel like the current state of project instructions/grading is a bad representation of the student's achievement of the desired learning objectives (as stated in section 1.1 of each of the project instructions). 

What it felt like to me as a student, and I am apparently not alone in this perspective, is that your score on projects in this course was less of a measure of how well you could understand and implement the machine learning and trading concepts taught in the course, and much more a measure of how well you could read these instruction documents.

This is compared to the other 3 classes I have taken so far in the OMSCS program (AI, RAIT, and GA), where this issue of convoluted expectations for assignments was not a problem. For example, I personally felt that the projects in AI (6601) were much more challenging conceptually but the expectations were much more clearly communicated, so getting a good grade on those assignments was actually easier! (for me, mileage may vary)

This was my first course in omscs, and I loved the class. It warmed me up to python and programming in general, which will be handy in the trimesters to come. The class is very well run. Project descriptions were detailed and clear (especially if you attend the TA live sessions). The only shortcoming of the course overall was the delayed grading. Other that that, I had fun!
If it is optional to take, skip this course. It will not add to your knowledge in trading or ML. In general, David's courses are only a waste of time.

Pros:
* you will learn some stock trading term&knowledge that is useful and fun to know nowadays
* Well organized course material overall with 8 projects and 2 exams with detailed criteria
* Discussion page with lots of students asking question and TAs are actively answering it (I admitted that I didn't use that very often and mostly for complaining my regrading process sorry but I think people are there to help)
Cons:
* 4 out of 8 projects needs you to write somewhat formal reports with some unnecessary details you need to follow(or not if you don't mind lose a chunk of points) which I think is better just convert into several canvas questionnaires
* unlike the strict report requirement, the example codes are very sloppy with weird spacing, empty lines, inconsistent naming style, and you will have to manually type in your student ID and username. Function signature got changed from project to project even though they expect you to reuse the code. Pointing these out is that all those combined, I feel the unfairness where the instructor demands a lot of unnecessary details while s/he doesn't care at all the details.
* In order to prevent GenAI usage, exam are now tuned so that it is also hard for normal human to read. Each exam contains 110 T/F questions but was advertised as 22 questions because for each 5 of them it will come with a irrelevant questions header, making it a multiple choices questions. I got caught off-guard and did pretty bad on my exam 1.
* Regrade process is taking forever and my issue never got resolved. This course is I think the most BUREAUCRATIC course I've ever seen. To be able to regrade your assigment, you will first need wait at least a day after the the TA's comments to be elligible for the regrading, BUT, not too late as after a week, you lose elligibility. I submitted regrading request 2/19 and never get any feedback until 5/5, a week before the semester ends. The TA gives feedback that is not relevant to what I asked and I was never able to get a second opinion after that.
All in all, I think for someone with limited python skills and enthusiast in stock trading might find this course very interesting, but if you are comfortable with one of a scripting language and just want to briefly broaden your horizon, the course might be a bit waste of time and you might find yourself, like me, lost in the red tape of OMSCS

This course has very interesting content and gives a great, broad overview of a lot of ML concepts. The lectures were fun to watch, and the projects were interesting. I would have given this a 5, but there were a few things that were big detractors. In reality, I'd give this course a 3.5, but rounded down due to the detractors. 

For starters, the exams are the worst exams I've ever taken. They're not the worst because of difficulty, they are just awfully written and impossible to study for. The exams are mostly on the readings, not the lectures, and the wording and format make them extremely poor tests of your knowledge. The instructional staff insists that the exams are good because of statistical measures, but they are so awful that every student I spoke to hated them. And they're worth more than a 1/3rd of your grade, so they can easily cause you get a letter grade lower than you expect. 

The projects are interesting, but the reports are a huge pain, and the report instructions are long, but often missing key information. I had to scour the Ed Discussions forums for TA answers to questions to fully get the correct instructions for each report. 
Unfortunately, I feel like the reports and exams are bringing this course down. From what i've read, it seems like it used to be a much better course.

Overall: This was my first OMSCS course along with one other. Overall, it's a very well-organized and well taught course. I would highly recommend it as a first course in the program and as a lighter introduction to machine learning without a strong math requirement. Stock market asset trading is an interesting machine learning domain for the projects. This course sets you up well with good tools and background for the OMSCS program in general.

Background: B.S. in Computer Science and 3.5 YOE as a SWE. No prior Python experience.

If you have no prior Python experience, Georgia Tech's course on EdX will prepare you for the Python background necessary for this course: 

https://www.edx.org/certificates/professional-certificate/the-georgia-institute-of-technology-introduction-to-python-programming?index=product&queryID=bde3583077b6ac1013a33913a38f71e1&position=5&linked_from=autocomplete&c=autocomplete

It is certainly possible to do well in this course with no prior Python experience. Just understand you will need to add in extra hours to what others may have reported here to learn Python and its libraries (and especially the ins and outs of graphing for report figures). I put in dozens of additional hours in the first 3 weeks to complete the Python certificates above to get the necessary background for the projects. Get the Python background ahead of time if you know you will take this course!

Projects: My biggest advice is to start projects early and to carefully review project assignments and go through their rubric's grading your own assignments for reports. When in doubt, make sure you've answered a rubric component thoroughly. My biggest grade loss was due to small oversights on Project 6's report (60%). Project 3 and Project 8 are the most time intensive and difficult but certainly possible to do well on - I got 100% and 95% on them respectively. I found project 7 on Reinforcement Learning to be by far the most interesting! I honestly enjoyed every project in the course, however!

Readings: I personally did all of them - they help on exams the most and tend not to be as necessary for the projects but can be good for citation material in reports.

Reports: Some students hated having to do these in addition to writing code for a project. You have to understand this is a graduate-level course to prepare you to be able to conduct research in machine learning, however. Therefore, communicating your experiments and methodologies is a useful skill. I didn't have much of this in my undergrad CS coursework (only in Biology) before so I enjoyed it. I also thought they helped me summarize and learn the material better. Start early and carefully review your submission like you're a grading TA with the rubric to make sure you've covered your bases and you'll do well.

Exams: The lectures, readings, and projects will help you prepare best. Never figured how to prepare well for these even though I did above average - they are time-pressured and difficultly phrased - they are not typically straightforward questions and sometimes hard to interpret. Sometimes I felt I knew the material for a question but was confused by the question itself. Time efficiency is the most important skill for the exams. I recommend making a table of contents for your notes in your notebook. Answer questions quickly and mark ones you're less sure on. Then return to those questions and use your notes or ChatGPT (which is allowed on exams in this course) on the questions you were less sure on with any remaining time.

Difficulty: This is a demanding course especially if you don't have a Python background - be disciplined and don't take it lightly. An 'A' is certainly achievable, however. I ended the course with a relatively safe A (~93%) despite not having a Python background at the start.

This was my first OMSCS course and I feel that it was a great introduction to the program. The first few weeks were a bit slow which gave me some time to acclimate to school again. There were a lot of reviews on here about project 3 being tough but I didn't think it was that bad, as well as all of the other projects. As long as you start early and thoroughly understand all of the course content prior to starting the projects, they should not be bad. I time tracked my projects, here are the logs if it can be helpful for anyone. 
Project 1: 12.5 hours
Project 2: 10 hours
Project 3: 35 hours
Project 4: 3.5 hours
Project 5: 10 hours
Project 6: 21 hours
Project 7: 10.5 hours
Project 8: 46 hours
I did enjoy the projects and thought that the course material was good. Some weeks had heavy required reading and I thought that the exams were tough but decent. I would recommend, but I do not think I would advise taking this as a summer class as none of the course content is removed.

My background: full-stack SWE with 2 years of experience but little Python experience, and no CS undergrad. This was my first course here. Ended with 98%.

+: The readings are all pretty good IMO. I did all the readings and I thought that all but 1 of the textbooks are quite interesting.
+: As long as you do the readings and watch the lectures, you will come away with decent (but shallow) knowledge of the ML landscape.
+: You'll also come away with shallow knowledge related to finance and investing. Nothing you couldn't learn on your own though.
+: Most of the projects are interesting and rewarding.

-: Assignment requirements are disorganized. You can't find all the requirements just by looking at the rubric; instead you'll need to close read the entire project document, as well as read Ed posts. This is a strange choice, since it wouldn't be impossible to put all the requirements in one place.
-: Projects are graded extremely slowly. If you're confident you're doing well and understanding everything, this is fine, but if you're struggling, you are not going to get feedback until it's too late. On top of that, many projects are built on previous projects, so that exacerbates the issue.
-: The exam questions and answers are explicitly designed to confuse ChatGPT, because the exams are open-book and open-internet. Unfortunately, that means these questions are harder for people to understand too. The wording is unnecessarily opaque / vague. This affects everyone, but particularly unfairly hurts non-native speakers.

• The first module was mainly about learning to use Numpy and Pandas. If you have no prior exposure to them (like me), that's probably good, otherwise, probably boring time.

The weak points of the course are real. That said, if you're interested in the subject, and confident that you'll do fine, you'll probably have a good time.

I took ML4T as my first class for OMSCS, and it was a great introduction to the program. Lectures average to about 1 hour per week, with readings (optional) averaging about 2 hours per week. Besides projects 3, 7, and 8, the rest were relatively easy and didn't take me more than a day, but they were still great applications of the concepts that we learned during lecture. I actually really liked project 3 because it was the first time I created a learning model from scratch, and project 8 was very satisfying because it was a combination of projects 3, 5, 6, and 7 together! If you are thinking about taking this class, I highly recommend it, and here is my advice for you: don't fall behind on lecture content, and make sure you give yourself ample time for each project. You will use the code you write for each project for a future project, so if you don't do well on one project, you will likely have to make it up. I also learned a lot about trading (didn't know anything before) and thought it was a great intro to financial concepts as well!

This is a brilliant starter course for the OMSCS program. If you're rusty with programming and/or are picking it back after a long hiatus, this course would provide the perfect opportunity for you to ease back into it. It may also work out quite alright for people who haven't had any meaningful exposure to coding in the past, or come from a non-CS undergrad. On the other hand, if you're someone with an extensive programming base (i.e. doing this right after a rigorous CS undergrad or working in software engg./data science), this course may not offer all that much value. Maybe one of the easier courses out there to cruise through in the pursuit of getting closer to your degree. The Trading or ML knowledge at hand is quite superficial - it offers you inspiration, at best, to do your own research and figure out try out quantitative finance. 

In terms of level of difficulty, I felt this course was similar to that of a year 2 or year 3 undergrad CS course - nothing too rigorous. If you score above 90 overall, you get an A. Although the faculty didn't officially post any stats on final grades distribution, looking at the distribution of individual project/exam grades, I wouldn't be surprised if at least 50% of the class ended up with an A. You have to put in effort, of course, and they will make you work for it, but grabbing an A is very much in sight. Personally, I would recommend absolutely ensuring all your project code passes through the tests they've designed, and adhering very meticulously to the grading rubric for all your reports/code. Getting 100% in all your assignments is completely within reach and practical. Exams are another thing though - you will almost certainly lose some points there, but nothing worth fretting over. Do your projects well, and the rest will take care of itself. 

For what it's worth, I really enjoyed this course as a way of starting my OMSCS journey, getting back in touch with coding after years and building confidence again. Also didn't read any of the prescribed books and in hindsight, it wouldn't have mattered from a grades perspective anyway. I feel I'm now ready to take some of the more difficult courses and/or embark on any side projects myself.

Pros:
- Improved my Python skills tremendously, I was incredibly shocked with how much easier I was able to put stuff together at the end of the year. 
- Early assignments slowly build confidence and don't take as much time.
- Video Lectures are best I've had in the program (only 3 courses), they teach stuff in a straightforward manner. 

Cons:
- Joyner papers are kind of a pain in the butt with all the formatting, do not leave these for the day before. I think I got caught a few times up till 3-4am finishing them up.

Not very difficult or overall time consuming, but the course content ended up feeling surface-level and borderline pseudoscientific. 

The projects are specified to fairly exhausting detail. If you're new to python this structure is nice, but otherwise it felt like jumping through arbitrary hoops to get full credit. 

AI4R, ML, RL, and AI cover this content in more depth without nickel and diming you on the rubric. 

Unless you're interested in trading specifically, or want a lot of direction for projects, I don't think ML4T is worth the time.

Nice course. Not so much to learn but indeed a good intro to ML and nice application to trading. The projects are designed fair enough and the notes provided are in detail and very useful for exams.
Suggest you take another course at the same time.

- Content is easy to understand.
- Programming assignments are easy to understand (I had prior Python/Numpy/Pandas knowledge).
- Reports require Joyner format, which made me anxious about potentially messing up my formatting.
- Assignments take forever to grade, so you don't have any bearing on your report style/formatting until nearly halfway through the course.
- Quizzes were open book but were a poor test of knowledge and were often more of an egg hunt for "meta" course content.

The content of the course is interesting and structured well. I believe this was the first semester they had the midterm and final exams as open book/internet - iirc the only restriction was no communication with other people during the exams. The questions seemed to be much more difficult than practice qns provided (which I believe reflects the exam style of previous semesters). Exams were not difficult but the wording of qns can be confusing and a 1hr time limit to review 100+ t/f statements means that you're generally working off of knowledge and only looking up a few qns here or there. Marks were scaled for exams - exam out of 110 and students would receive the mark out of 100. Essentially disregarding 10 incorrect answers.

As others have mentioned the assignments are extremely detail oriented. There is a long document with all the assignment requirements + a 1.5-2hr weekly TA session going over quiz answers and walking through the assignment. I got full marks on all the coding sections but lost marks on seemingly unimportant details in the report like a line color on a graph. It would be great if the auto-grader could provide more informative feedback as all the assignments are related. Receiving marks and feedback 4 weeks after submission sometimes delays progress on subsequent assignments. Start early on assignment 3 and 8 if you can, those are the most time consuming! Most other assignments required <5hrs to complete.

I would recommend this as as starter course for OMSCS. Prof. Joyner is top notch, the content is interesting and not difficult. TAs are very responsive, make sure to keep an eye on Ed Discussions. It's a great course to ease back into studies.

Summary:
Overall, this course was just fine. If you're like me and just want an introduction to ML and have no ML background, then this is a great course. However, it is taught like an undergraduate course, so there is less personal responsibility, but the "coddling" takes up some unnecessary time.

Pros:
-Great intro to ML
-Easy, material isn't difficult to understand
-Gives some good introductory material to ML and Finance

Cons:
-Project and exam expectations are distributed across Ed discussion, weekly recorded office hours, and the course website. You need to read all of these very thoroughly to understand the expectations of the projects.
-The reports are sometimes tedious. These aren't too bad but they take a lot of time and don't add much more value than a question/answer worksheet would.

This course has potential but it is not executed very well. They could focus on more applicable concepts pertaining to quant trading (how to construct software systems to execute automatic trades, options theory, types of trading strategies, and so much more that they should’ve covered but didn’t). The graders are incredibly tough and will mark off points just because they feel like it when the work you’ve provided is perfectly sufficient. This course opened my eyes to nothing and taught me nothing I didn’t already know from other ML courses (the ML they teach us also taught poorly) and rudimentary research. Do not recommend this course.

An incredibly interesting class. Honestly I cannot find it in another place. The only downside is that they caught me copying from another github for like 20 lines of matplotlib code and flagged me with a 0 and a warning. Be careful! The professor is nice and smart. Highly recommend to any new comers. Keep up the great shit!

Having machine learning knowledge from undergraduate, the class was not hard at all. The course achieves what it sets out to. You do not finish the class with knowledge of how to make a profit in the stock market. However, you finish with the knowledge of what is needed to make a profit in the stock market. A lot of people (like the clown below me) rates the course 1/5 because they forget it's "machine learning for trading" and not just "machine learning". Don't come into this class expecting to be Andrew Ng making a million dollars from the stock market - it's an intro course.
The focus is on stuff unrelated to learning.

Sigh. I kinda wish I didn't take this course. The two main things I got out of it were: 1) don't try to beat the market (just invest in index funds) and 2) it turned me off from taking any other machine learning courses in the program.

I'd rate the course as a whole a 4/5 for everything besides the final project, and a 2/5 for the final project. Also, I'd give it a difficulty of 3/5 for everything besides the final project and a 5/5 for the final project.

I found the trading material the most interesting, but I doubt I'll ever utilize any of that knowledge in the real world. The machine learning topics were also interesting, but I don't feel like I gained a good grasp of them through the projects or readings.

Exams weren't bad considering I thoroughly reviewed the relevant lectures and readings. Both were essentially 110 T/F questions with 10 points being extra credit. There was a bit of a time crunch though as they only give you about an hour. I found that it helped to pace myself by only giving myself 30 seconds per T/F statement.

The TAs are great. Very, very responsive and very helpful. I also really enjoyed the lectures and the What Hedge Funds Really Do book. The books on machine learning were all pretty over my head. I just tried to memorize what I could for the exams but nothing from them ever really clicked.

Okay, so now the projects. I loved the first few. Project 3 was tough but I put the time in reviewing all the relevant material and got it working. I was so happy that I broke out into an impromptu dance. Project 6 (technical indicators) was also rather time intensive but I enjoyed researching and writing about each indicator. 

So, I assumed that as long I could invest a large chunk of time into Project 8 that I would get a good grade and be happy with the results. Well, not really. Essentially felt like 2 weeks (80 hours or so?) of trial and error. I really, really wish that they gave some more direction on it. I attended office hours, reviewed the lectures, all the posts on Ed Discussion. It was kind of heartbreaking. I still got a B on the final project but I don't feel like I deserved it considering I failed half the test cases.

I typically feel that a hard earned B is more valuable than an easy A, but I couldn't tell you what I got out of that final project. I envy the other students who were able to bring all the previous projects together into something that worked in project 8.

For context, my undergraduate background is in STEM with a minor in CS. I paired this course with Deep Learning for the semester and feel like the schedules of these two classes worked together extremely well. There were only two weeks where assignments/quizzes for each class landed on the same week. 

I enjoyed this course, but more for its introduction to finance topics than for any content on machine learning. You definitely get out what you put into this course. 
TA team was excellent. They engaged with the students in the forum quickly and were helpful in answering questions. Sometimes they came off as condescending, but this was in situations of people repeatedly asking the same questions or not taking the time themselves to search the forums. 
One thing that is important to note is that the exam format of this course has changed, from multiple choice to a multi-select format. This increased the difficulty of the exams slightly from what I had expected based on previous reviews. 
Projects for this course were enjoyable/interesting but tedious, with 25-50% of the time on the project being spent on the actual implementation, and 50-75% of the time being spent on looking through the 10-20 page project writeup and making sure that no points would be deducted for having an incorrectly colored line in a graph or using a list instead of a NumPy array. 
With so many people taking the course concurrently, it is understandable that they have standardized the assignments to provide quicker turnaround time in grading. While long, the assignment writeups communicate all expectations for the project, its just a matter of tracking down the requirements.

Subjective Project Difficulty Ranking:
8 > 3 > 6 > 5 > 1 > 2 > 4

Would I take this course again? Maybe. I learned a lot about finance in this course but felt like most of the course difficulty came from tedious assignment requirements.

My background is EE not CS, and I worked 40-60 hours a week. (generally 40 hours but closer to 60 hours for 1/4 of this semester).  I was familiar with PyCharm, Pandas, and Numpy prior to this course however I would not have called myself an expert (had only used that a handful of times).  I was also a little familiar with basic trading so some of the financial concepts taught were not new to me.  This was my first class at OMSCS.

Class wasn't difficult per se - if you took notes while watching the lectures carefully, paid attention to the discussions happening on Ed, and reviewed or attended the live weekly sessions, then I think you'll do fine on the exams and quizzes. 

Challenge came from the projects which there were 8 total; some were easy and straightforward but many were time consuming and challenging to implement.   Some projects even build upon previous projects so if you missed something on a previous project, you'll need to go back and fix them.  All very do-able and in my opinion (for the "harder projects", there are even recorded lectures on how to think about/implement your project), not impossible to complete successfully for full points.

25 Hours a week is an estimate - most weeks I'd dedicate 5 hours during the week and around 15 hours on the weekend but there were 2 or 3 weeks where I put around 40 due to projects.  Again, not hard, just time consuming to write and debug all that code.

Lectures are fine and I got by with mostly using them, only touched the textbooks the week of an exam.  

I don't understand the people who complain about the lectures being out dated.  Sure they were recorded a while back but the material in them is still valid.  Reading reviews and posts on Reddit makes me think that people were expecting to be able take the material taught here and immediately be qualified to work as a quant/use your final project to begin day trading.  In one of the weekly discussions early in the semester,, we were told that this course was meant to introduce us to financial concepts and trading, introduce us to ML algorithms, and set us up so we're at a place we can continue our studies if we were interested in learning more.  If you come in with that mindset, you'll see that there is definitely a lot of value to this course.

Final Thoughts: Great first class, definitely learned a lot about ML, finance, and even learned a few new things I could do using Python. I wouldn't let any negative reviews discourage you if you're even mildly interested in any of these topics.

-Oh Man... Least favorite course in the program (this was my 10th and final one). Please Take another course.
-Lectures recorded in 2016 and handful in poor quality.
-Course policy makes the 2 exam brutal experiences compared to other courses. Exam topics are secret and information it not as transparent as it seems.
-The coding projects are easy if you are comfortable, and get fairly tricky towards the end. The description for the projects takes hours to digest its ridiculous imo.
-If you want to learn about stock trading this course talks about obsolete approaches and in fact laughs about what we learned in a final interview you have to watch. Just watch video online about stocks you'll have a better experience.

Out of the 30 or so Georgia Tech courses I've taken so far across BSCS and MSCS, ML4T is the final course in my degree and is also the worst in terms of overall quality. 

Criticisms and areas for improvement:

- The quality of the lectures also need to be improved. Some of the videos are hour long lectures recorded live several years back. Because the original professor, Dr. Balch, no longer teaches the course, no changes have been made to the curriculum. Having trading lectures from a College of Business professor and ML lectures from a College of Computing professor would dramatically enhance the quality of the lectures. At the moment it is below MOOC quality. 

- Reports for programming projects are busy work and should be replaced by a short set of questions about the results that can be answered with a few sentences. 

- The first assignment, Martingale, is pretty much irrelevant to the rest of the course. Replacing it with a short assignment covering vectorization, Pandas, and NumPy would be much more beneficial to the students.

- The Gradescope autograder is not properly utilized by the course. The final submission should run the full suite of tests and actually display the grade for the assignment. 

- The wording of exam questions is convoluted: sometimes proposing some scenario which requires additional time to parse, flips between positives and negatives (e.g. select all that are not X), and uses terms that were not used in the lectures. 

- Assignment descriptions are extremely long and formatting guidelines (areas for penalization) are scattered throughout. Definitely need to be reworked.

This was my first course in OMSCS.  Before starting the program I took a couple of classes in Java at a local university. This was my first class that used python and I had no prior exposure to ML concepts. However, I do have a STEM undergrad. 

I thought that this class was a good starter course. They are really soft graders for the reports. Framing the ML concepts with stock trading was interesting and provided for some fun projects. 

The only real con that there is a wide disparity between the projects in terms of time of completion. Some weeks the project took me less than 3 hours and some projects 3 and 8 took upwards of 40. The tests are also pretty difficult.

Easy class-having had past experience with numpy.  

I found the projects more tedious than interesting, especially given the exacting demands of the report formatting.

In all honesty, I took this class because I wanted to learn about investing, and was hoping for more of a focus on that from an individual investor perspective, but this is much more aimed at what to do if you want to work in a hedge fund.  

I could see it being a little more rushed during a summer semester, but in fall it was a nice breather before more difficult courses.

Listen up, folks! This course can get pretty tough, especially P3 and P8, which are no walk in the park. I won't lie, even I had my struggles with P1, so don't take it lightly. 

Seriously, don't wait until the last day to do your projects. The readings can be overwhelming, and you'll need to put in some serious time to get a handle on everything especially if you want to read the unrequired martials.

TL;DR: Unless you are ready to sweat every weekend over irritating coding tasks, do NOT take this course if you are not familiar with Python and some of its libraries like NumPy, Pandas etc. which are commonly used in ML.

Background - Undergrad in CS + 2yrs of SWE experience at big-tech.

I hoped that this course would be a gentle introduction to the world of ML, given that most of my background and experience has been systems oriented. However, being completely unfamiliar with Python and its ML-specific libraries, 99% of my time was spent in banging my head over how to transform a numpy array, or how to plot a graph with appropriate legends / axes using mathplotlib (plus the overly detailed and completely meaningless specifications for plotting graphs for each project). 

And to top if off, you're expected to present your analysis for each project in the format of a research paper, which again involves so much grunt work.

In terms of conceptual learnings, this course is virtually useless. I learnt way more during a 4-week ML concepts seminar at my undergrad than whatever this entire course has to offer.

So if you don't know Python based ML, get ready for hours of grunt work that will take up every weekend (almost every week requires a project or assignment to be submitted). 

Totally not worth it if you're planning to specialize in Systems. If you just want to learn ML, I'd rather recommend watching a youtube video series somewhere.

I go over every detail (in 5 mins) of this class, check it out!
https://youtu.be/lFupZlo2pnw

The general perception of this class is fairly accurate, but I think what is not mentioned is how much farther you can take the content if you want to. I didn’t do the readings and got an A. Exams are MC, straightforward, and weighted relatively lightly. I rate difficulty as easy when in reality the difficulty could be harder if you set yourself to a higher standard. The first week or two feels like an introduction to python/pandas/numpy, but after that the class is 50/50 between trading and introductory ML. the TAs (who predominantly run the class) are responsive in forums, provide clarity in office hours, and encourage discussion and deeper analysis whenever possible.

As someone who does not want to pursue ML, I took this class because I thought it would be a nice introduction to it (in addition to being interested in investing).

The content was really interesting. My biggest gripes were that I do not like writing reports (which is what I spent the most time on) and (and the reason for the lower overall rating) it took a while to get feedback on assignments (this improved after the middle of the semester, but we still waited on ~50% of our total grade until then). Follow up regrade requests also took a while to address.

First semester was Spring 2023 in OMSCS program. Was a bit nervous about getting back into school and wanted to take something more mellow. ML4T hit the marks as its using python and of a subject that I'm familiar with already (ML). The class I believe is structured well. The projects are paired with grading scripts which, if you pass all tests, you get full marks on the project. However, there is still the report aspect of it but these are straight forward as well. Ensure that you answer all of the questions or bullets they list for the project and you WILL do well. The hardest part IMO about writing the report was using Professor Joyners document format as I have been use to MLA or APA from previous classes. While I did enjoy this class, I do, looking back now, feel that I slightly wasted one of the classes I could have taken. Not saying that this is a bad class but there are so many great options being offered that I currently can't decide which would be the best to take and already losing out one slot is slightly upsetting when I could take something significantly more interesting or more high-level as ML4T seems to only scrape across the top of each subject. Coming in as a new student, this class is a great choice but looking back now, you could get way more value from other classes. 
Forgot to mention, exams are straight forward multiple choice - study the practice questions/exams they give and you'll be fine so long as you do well on those. 

--------Difficulty---------------------
 3/5 - except p3 which is 5/5 and p8 which is just extremely time consuming 4/5 

--------Rating-----------------------
4/5 -  as a brand new student
2.5/5 - looking back, kinda wish I took a different course as I didn't learn too much from it

The full review can be found in my post:

https://the11d.wordpress.com/2023/06/09/my-thoughts-on-ml4t-omscs-review-1/

Was split between between a 2 and 3 on this. On course content I would give it a 3, or potentially event 4. However, the way this course was run and administered made me want to rip my hair out. This course could be good, but the way it's run is just so frustrating to participate with.

Pros:
- Overall pretty mellow in terms of workload and difficulty. Brief hotspots like project 3 and project 8
- Exams are very easy. I think you could have never watched a single lecture and probably get a 75%
- Projects are (for the most part) fairly interesting, and good practice of python programming
- Lectures are kind of high-level and shallow, but at least mostly interesting
- Exposure to basic concepts of finance. May or may not be interesting depending on student interests.

Cons:
- The project assignments are these overly pedantic, litigious tomes. They make an Apple Terms of Service contract seem consumer friendly. 
- The TA team has this faux-hyper-positive tone, but are condescending and generally not helpful.
- There are 8 projects in the course, and we didn't receive a single graded assignment until project 6. Student's are not given a meaningful chance to course correct.
- On the projects, they levy massive grade penalties over tedious minutia. Meanwhile, some of my writing was absolute garbage, yet somehow scores 100. Basically, the projects largely boil down to an exercise in box-checking by the faculty.

I took the course in Spring 2023 and ended up getting full marks throughout. Apart from finance, I do not think I learnt much from this course. I did not like the ML part a lot, not because I work in ML, but because I don't think this is a good way to learn ML. 

Pros
1. TAs were super responsive and helpful. 
2. The lectures are well-organized.
3. Good first course if you have non-CS background.

Cons
1. The lecture content is slightly outdated. This was my first sem and I was surpised that lectures with errors/mistakes have been used continously since 2017. Atleast add some on-screen info during the lectures.
2. Basics ML stuff like cross-validation or out-of sample testing were completely ignored in P8. I would recommend students to do this themselves.
3. TA live sessions were unnecessarily long. They were filled with generic and unnecessary remarks, useless boasting from a member of teaching staff about how he would conduct interviews. I would request the TAs to keep TA live sessions short, specially if you refer to it while answering queries. If possible, provide rough timestamps. 
4. The same member of the teaching staff (mentioned above) provides generic responses very frequently. Responses like 'do debugging, it helps' are completely useless. 

Students taking this course
1. Read the assignment wiki, listen to TA sessions and follow Ed regularly. You'll be fine.
2. Do practice questions for Exam 1 (30 question pdf) and Exam 2 (100s of questions). Everything is from these.
3. Do not limit yourself to what is being taught in the class. If you want to learn more, you can do a lot more than what is required.

An alright course overall. I went in expecting the "for trading" aspect to be more of a framing device to learn about machine learning, but a significant portion of the class is dedicated to teaching about stock trading, so don't expect an incredibly deep dive into the "ML" part.

The majority of projects are very straightforward and some can be done in just a few hours. Most have fairly long reports associated with them, but grading is lenient as long as you make sure to follow the rubric.

Both exams are just a couple dozen easy multiple choice questions, but the study material for them is pretty bad -- the practice exams are years old and don't cover all the same content as the modern class.

This is a great starter course for OMSCS and gives you a general idea of what to expect out of a course! (In this course, some background in Python, Numpy, Pandas, and/or Matplotlib is recommended though)
This was my first course in the program too and was overall a good experience to warm up and adjust to the pace of the program. 

Pros:
- Great responsive TAs (Both Ed and Slack, mostly Ed)
- The assignment schedule for all assignments is released in advance, so you can frontload work if needed, but even otherwise the pace is reasonable for a longer semester (Fall/Spring)
- Can serve as a great warmup for ML (Decision Trees/Q-Learning), also gives a basic intro to some Finance concepts
- Easy exams (both midterm and final), shouldn't require more than 2-3 days of prep each, and easy quizzes

Cons:
- Slightly dated lecture material (still well organized in Ed lessons)
- Assignment requirements are lengthy and pedantic (As other students said, you know something's off if TAs are asking you to use a highlighter on the grading rubric) and others reported marks being deducted for (minor) issues like printing to the console/plotting windows, on top of which sometimes FAQs are needed to cover up even more details that are unintentionally omitted, which can make the whole experience a bit of a hassle.
- Less learning for people who already have a background in Finance or ML (It touches only the basics of both and not much in-depth)
- Projects 3 and 8 can be big, not due to the complexity/challenge, but due to the sheer number of moving parts needed to complete these assignments (but I guess every course in OMSCS has these), my advice is to start these two as early as possible and not leave it for the last weekend :P
- It takes a long time for grading and for any feedback on your work (in our case, only 3 batches of grades were released one before the drop deadline, one near the last project's deadline, and one near the end-of-term)

At the start of the year, I began my Master’s program at Georgia Tech University. However, in the first semester, I faced various difficulties. Despite this, I managed to perform well (result not out but hopeful). I particularly enjoyed taking ML4T as my first course. I chose it based on reviews from OMSCS Central and my specialization. The registration day was like a quick and exciting flash sale on Amazon, and all seats were booked within a minute.

ML4T is an excellent introductory course for learning about finance and machine learning concepts. Since I already knew these concepts, the course only took about 5–7 hours per week, except for the last few project weeks. I learned how to write Decision Tree and Bag Learners from scratch using numpy, which was a great hands-on experience. The course also covered reinforcement learning and Q-Learning, and I got to create a Q-Learning model from scratch for a trading use case, which was a valuable learning experience.

Besides machine learning, this course also taught me financial concepts that have made me a better investor. I learned that even choosing a server location can be a significant decision for high-frequency trading companies.

Learning about amazing financial concepts has certainly improved my investing thought process. Now, I understand the meaning of Alpha, Beta, Sharpe Ratio, and the volatility of a fund. I have learned to evaluate stocks based on fundamental and technical analysis.

I also learned about the Efficient Frontier portfolio, which is a risk vs return plot that helps identify the best option with minimum risk and maximum return. I have gained knowledge about mean-variance optimization, which involves combining stocks that have anti-correlation in the short term and positive correlation in the long term.

Additionally, I received an explanation of options trading and profit and loss plots. I also learned about options strategies like the Covered Call and ButterFly techniques. EMH and CAPM concepts were really valuable.

In total, the course consisted of two exams and eight projects. OMSCentral currently rates this course with a difficulty of 2.5 and a workload of approximately 11.2 hours. However, I found that I needed much less time to complete the course, and I generally studied for about 5–7 hours per week. I often completed my work over the weekends. This course does have report writing, so try to be an efficient writer, but reports are not that long.

Overall, I highly recommend this course as an OMSCS starter.

While this course may look like 'clickbait' it is actually really good. The first 7 projects cover a wide range of finance and machine learning topics, with everything magically coming together in the 8th capstone project.

While the workload is not heavy, it is relentless. Taking a week off can create time-management problems. Taking two weeks off can trigger panic! Give up trying to follow the thousands of discussion topics on Ed and instead stay laser-focused on the schedule.

This is one of the best courses in the OMS program and I would consider it a "must take" if you are in OMSCS or OMSA. The projects are pretty fulfilling especially the final project where you put all of the tools/techniques from previous projects together to develop your own AI/ML trading agent. It will not exactly translate into real-world trading but it is a good first step.

I signed up for this class despite reading how unorganized it was because I saw Dr. Joyner's name. Unfortunately, I don't think he got around to giving the Joyner's touch this semester.

For example, the final project's description was 25 pages long. There was a 1.5 hour long TA discussion video going over the project. Yet, there're still hundreds of posts asking for clarifications and even after you read through all those posts, you might still have questions. 

For the first half of the semester, no grades were released till right before the final drop deadline. I'm not sure why they insisted on not releasing any grade. It was very stressful as projects built on previous ones and I would much rather not have a "W" on my transcript if I had to drop.

If you're planning to take this class, I highly recommend reviewing numpy and pandas as well as read through the posts on the forum. Not all the project requirements are specified on the website; some are hidden in the posts and if you miss it, you miss it. There are also typos and mistakes throughout the lecture videos that won't be clarified unless someone posts about it. Also triple check the scoring guide before submitting. If you draw a black line instead of a red line for the graph, you can lose 10% of your grade.

This class was pretty easy. I'm almost done with RL this semester and comparing the two, this class was probably half as much work.

This is a great first course, or if you need a break. There is still a decent amount of work here so if you expect it to be a complete pushover, you will be hurting. Nothing is too difficult and if you follow the instructions its pretty hard to not get an A. If you took RL or ML, I probably would not take this class as the ML techniques taught in this class are pretty basic. 

If you are interested in the stock market I would recommend it, but if you already know about options and technical analysis I would not take this class, as that's probably most of the value I took away from this class.

Pros: 
Overall, I enjoyed this class and learned a lot. I gained the ability to use numpy, pandas, matplotlib libraries and learned to write papers describing experiments. The TA staff are fantastic and ML4T offers a lot of engagement in Ed as well as with the office hours and supplemental material. 

Cons: 
I would say the less enjoyable parts of the course were following along some of the videos that are of low video quality or resolution. The project descriptions are lengthy and you have to spend a lot of time making sure you tick each requirement.

Time Required: 
I timetracked my work and logged 185 hours over 16 weeks for an average of 11.56 hours/week. I have previous exp. working in python and this was my 2nd class in OMSCS. The time commitment varies per assignment and can be lumpy on a week to week basis. It is possible to speedrun the course, as some folks did in my term. 

(Please note, this class does require a lot of writing. If this is not your preference, it may be less enjoyable in that aspect and require additional effort.) 

How to do well on exams:
Study the sample questions and make sure you can answer them all. They might mention to skip the questions on "The Big Short" movie, as they did in my term. 

How to do well on projects: 
-Download the project spec
-Go through every single line in the rubric
-Double check that you meet each requirement. (You must explicitly answer each line in the rubric!)
-Sleep on it
-Repeat this process until you are confident you match all requirements.
-Post your charts in the charts threads per project and compare against your peers' to make sure your work is correct

I'm in my second week of the course.  This is my first course in OMSCS. I have decades of professional experience working in equities trading technology (non-programming role). I took the pre-requisite Python course via Edx for 6 months leading up this class. Between the readings, lessons and project1 in the first 2 weeks I am spending 60 hours a week or more on this class so far. Despite those hours I am not able to complete the code for Project 1. Seems like a cool course if I can continue, but this is without a doubt the hardest course I have every taken in my life so far.  May have to withdraw or drop out completely from OMSCS.  I researched this course on omscentral in advance - so buyer beware with the workload estimates on here!

As with a lot of these reviews, I think people who are quick like to commend themselves on it and talk about how easy it is, but for most of us, this class in fact is not ultra easy and will take some work. That being said, it's very doable.

Intellectually, the concepts are decently challenging at times and will take some time to wrap your head around. Other times, the assignments are intellectually straight forward and you just need to code them (ie. market simulator). For example, creating a decision tree assignment is not a cake walk, but the stringent requirements also are a large contributing factor. You will likely need to actively seek out the material offered in the class, like the extra recitations, etc. and watch lectures again to understand some concepts and get a good start. That being said, it's not insanely impossible to do, you just need butt-in-seat time to get it done.

The stringent requirements are really bad though. I spent hours pouring over the details of the requirements and still messed some of them up.

The exams are akin to undergrad history or music electives with a CS twist: sit there and ingest a few hundred practice questions until you can regurgitate them onto the test.

This is an interesting class the TAs are helpful and the course is structured well. 
Problems-
1) The course is structured so that 2 assignments are worth a big chunk of your grade and take up a lot of time. Some assignments I literally finished by being in a TA office hour session for 30 mins, right there. The big ones are the Asses Learners(15%)and p8(20%) every other project is worth 3-8 percent of your grade. The first project is kind of like a filter imo. Its not hard but if you let it sneak up on you and don't work ahead of time it WILL absolutely hurt your grade. 

Good things-
Office hours with the TAs (which are everyday) help a tonne. The exams are not too hard if you study the material and revise it well you be able to do well.

I really enjoyed using Python libraries to analyze stock data. The first seven projects build up to a pretty open-ended Project 8, the capstone, in which we trained a model on real stock data. I feel like building a model to earn money on the stock market is something that most CS people want to do but never get around to actually doing; I found the projects rewarding and I really enjoyed hyperparameter tuning for Project 8. 

This was not a terribly hard course. The highlight for me was spending so much time learning NumPy and Pandas. 

The project descriptions are detailed, so the projects can be completed ahead of time. 

Project tips: 
1) Make sure your code compiles without issue in Gradescope, passing all tests.
2) Be deliberate about following all instructions. 
3) Don't spend time staring at a bug; look at Ed forums. 
4) Watch the TA Live Discussions live or close to live. 
5) Start the report early because it can take a while to generate visualizations, etc. Definitely not the fun part of the project but very important for your grade.

Exam tip: Watch the lecture videos on time or early and take notes. Make sure that you understand all of the concepts on the exam review and you'll do fine.

I got an A! This was the worst class I took in OMSCS. The content is very easy and you don't learn a lot. The class teaches some python (pandas, numpy etc.), some technical financial analysis and some ML (decision tree and Q-learning). Even though the content is easy, their stupid requirements can cost you a grade very easily. Make sure you read every single requirement and check that you did it all. I was almost gonna get a B from this class.

P.S. I took it in Fall 2021 but selected Spring 2022 because there was no such option.

This was my first class and I don’t regret my decision of starting the program with this class. The time commitment of this class depends on the projects. I recall one project easily taking 20-30 hrs, while other projects could easily take only a couple of hours. Will highly recommend people taking this class to always stay ahead of the game. Never underestimate how much time you’ll need for projects. Will definitively recommend to any students starting the program to start it with this class. Overall a great class A++

This is a weird course. 

It's not necessarily difficult in terms of understanding the material, but it's time-consuming and arduous to get all of the deliverables over the line for all of the reasons other students mentioned below. As in, it took me a much longer time to get some of the projects completed than the other two classes I've taken (GIOS and IIS), but I learned significantly less while doing so as most of my focus was on making sure I met the specified rubric rather than re-molding my brain to learn new ideas.

The TAs were always responsive, but I never got a helpful answer out of them. For instance, when I asked for clarification on a question on one of the reports, I got the answer: "Your probability is XXXX, and this is unlikely and too high in Q4. In Q5, your expectation is XXXX, which is also unlikely and too low. I recommend checking your simulation results." Asking a student to 'check their results' when they've already submitted a clarification request asking for how they could've thought about the problem differently isn't useful.

We get quick grades on the exams, but we have to put in a special request to see which questions we got wrong and we don't get an answer key.

We are required to submit multiple reports and projects, with a stretch of a month where we have a project due every single week where all projects build on one another, but we have to wait over a month to get the grades back potentially repeating the same error or assumption across multiple, ungraded projects.

All of the assignments are released at the beginning of the semester, so it's possible to get started on any project ahead of time. This is great, except it has the net effect of different tranches of students working on different parts of the course, so the EdStem forum is a mish-mash of questions and, more importantly, students who had *got it* and turned in their assignments already don't help the other students while they're waiting for the next project. The moving in lockstep goes a long way to helping students feel like they're part of a whole - as it stands now, I felt like I was more alone in this course than others.

My goal for the class was to dip my toes into machine learning, and while I did get a reasonably understanding of both Q-learning and decision tree learners, I didn't have any moments in the class where I really had to stretch or get into conversations with fellow students or TAs to struggle to that 'ah-ha!' moment that I did the other courses that I took.

It feels like since there's not a professor who has a background in finance that the material has drifted somewhat and the course lacks focus. So as it's gotten stale, the workload has increased by adding busy work that takes a long time and lacks meaningful feedback.

In summary, this class isn't difficult in the 'the material kicks your teeth in' kind of way, but it's difficult in the 'make sure you manage your time correctly and be confident that your work is correct' kind of way.

My advice for the course at the end of the day was to shunt the busy-work parts of the course to Gradescope, and give immediate feedback for those problems. Ground the students' basics with confidence and then make the programming assignments more difficult to encourage stretching.

The lectures are very clear and logically presented, and the content is well explained. The readings are informative as well. You won't need to complete optional readings for the exams and whatnot, but I suggest doing them anyways to get as much out of the course as possible. Otherwise, you may feel like you aren't learning a whole lot in terms of machine learning. The TAs are fantastic. The coding projects range from challenging to easy, and a few are accompanied by papers (no more than 10 pages long). The written, online specifications for the projects are a nightmare, however. They are unnecessarily long, full of repeated instructions, littered with inconsistenties and outdated info. I suggest setting aside 3-4 hourse to go through each one, making your own outline and logging any questions you may have. The study guide for the exams is also WAY outdated and basically useless. Don't use it. Just review the non-optional material you read and heard in lectures, and you will be fine. In summary, this class is GREAT except for the study guides and project instuctions. I would definitely recommend it.

I took it as my first course in my OMSCS journey. I am Computer Engineer by profession and did my MS in 1999. In my opinion, ML4T is a good course to take if you are looking for light work load or pair it with a hard one. It has very good course content and programming assignments(and report writing for some of the projects). It does not expect or require any prior Python/Numpy/Panda experience as you will get enough time to learn while taking the course.

I think the TAs are the best part of this class. I felt supported all the way. It was kind of a bummer though not to have Prof Joyner present in any online session. I legit thought my professor was Steven Bryant (shout out to this guy's diligence and the diligence of the TA staff as a whole)

Non-CS background here, 1st class, learned python on the go:
- From a content aspect, the course was not that challenging and I actually wish it covered more ML than finance (although you can argue this is ML "for trading") I wish there were updated and more lectures about and systematic trading because that's where ML is growing
- From a grading/assignment perspective, the class could use improvement: lengthy and unnecessary requirements that don't teach you anything and make graders and students miserable. I would much rather explore challenging topics then spend hours back and forth between Ed platform, TA sessions videos and reading requirements 10x 

Good starter class in my opinion and I would recommend it.

The material in this course was not all that challenging, however, the course was "hard" for me because I found the topic to be rather boring. The stock market does interest me, but having to write papers about small coding assignments was very unmotivating. I rated this course at a 3. I would say the material is a 2/5. Finding the motivation to write the reports and meet the deduction-heavy requirements of the projects made the course feel like a 3/5. In the future, I hope to stick to courses that have minimal writing.

Amazing class!

Highlights for me:
-	INCREDIBLE TAs. I had a private Ed post that literally *3* different TAs chimed in on. Amazing engagement and guidance from the whole team (and a special shoutout to Steven Bryant; he seemed like he was everywhere I turned on Ed)
-	Relevant, interesting lecture videos.
-	Projects were interesting and challenging
-	Loved that all assignments were released at the start of the semester. This allowed me to work ahead and spread the load throughout the semester.

Really no cons to this class. I guess some of the assignments were a bit slow to be graded, but what are they gonna do when there’s so many students…

Really one of the best organized and executed classes I’ve take so far!

Interesting content, love the projects. 

Exams suck and should be removed.

The reports, while nice in theory, make the grading take an ANNOYING amount of time.

Writing this review in the fall with a little more perspective after taking a few more courses. This is a good course with some major drawbacks that could easily be fixed if the staff were interested. I wanted to like the course more than I ultimately did. But it's still run decently (may be a commentary on other courses more than this one).

Pros
- TA's are very active. They're responsive on Ed forums and office hours are held multiple times every day. So if you're looking for help, you can get it easily
 - Course is very well taught. Dr. Balch makes the material very easy to understand from lecture videos
 - Material is interesting and a gentle introduction to ML / AI if you're just getting going to the program


Cons
 - Project description pages. Oh my god they're terrible. You'll waste hours deciphering these. I'm halfway through the OMSCS program, and this is the worst I've seen. They feel like they're written by 20 different people, printed out, thrown in the air, then put back in a random order. Sections are repeated but with slight differences that make it difficult to notice / figure out which version is correct. Other parts are repeated verbatim. Certain parts are repeated unnecessarily every project (we get how Gradescope works...don't need a section every time). Certain part are run-on paragraphs rather than bullets which make finding requirements difficult / easy to miss. And API examples might not reflect the requirements of the assignment (different dates, stock symbols, etc.). And in a 6,000+ word document, it's way too long to set students up for success. 

- Grading speed is terrible. With an auto-grader, this is inexcusable

- Papers. Lots of assignments have a paper alongside them, which is just academia for academia's sake. I didn't get anything from these. Removing these would also improve grading speed.

 - No feedback on code, so you could "pass poorly" and never know

There were times where the weekly course load was a few hours... and other where it was closer to 20. It really just depended on the week. Very good starter course. As a software engineer, I did not find the coding aspect of the course to be very challenging.

I was disappointed in the attitude of the TAs and grading policy. I never once spoke with any of them or engaged because right out of the gate they indicated all the ways you could ruin your grade and that if your code fails to run they'll just send you a sad face and an F. They also explain that asking about your grade could result in docking more points. I'm paraphrasing, but they might as well just say "Welcome to the course, we a group of bitter TAs who are tired of grading and hate students" -- the material is interesting, but I was so afraid to talk to them that it took away from my experience. I got a good grade, but sometimes was docked points without understanding why or how to improve (because the feedback is nonexistant) and just kept plowing forward not really understanding the point of the grading process. If given another chance, I would pick different course.

Also the video lectures are kinda light and fluffy... so that left me a little disappointed, as someone who would have liked to dive into the math and pseudo code a bit more.. I think they expect you to get that from the reading. I can buy books and read them without paying GA Tech for the privilage.

This is my first OMSCS course with a non-CS background. Overall, this is a great class for an introduction to ML and a first class. However like many have said, the course content can definitely use some rework/improvement. The projects are not hard but takes time, I would recommend this class for people who just starting the program or if you want to get some exposure to ML without taking the real ML class.

It’s my first course and I really enjoyed it. It’s a very good intro course to this program.

Background: bachelor and master in applied math.  No Python experience and it’s my only course

Final grade: 98.87%

Report: I used the latex template which helped on the reporting format.

Projects：the projcts are not trivial but alao not too difficult. I get to know more about Python, especially class and recursion. Also some ML models (decision tree and Q Learning) and trading knowledge (trading indicators)

Exams: just walk through the sample exam and you will be fine.

This is a very interesting course topically that I think has fallen apart as the original instructor has gotten away from the class.

Course projects are very time-consuming even though they aren't too difficult. Of the points I lost in this class, they were nearly all due to time constraints on my part rather than an inability to solve the problems. The class has been written to scale and requires interfacing with arbitrary API requirements to receive grades from gradescope that neither reflect real-world software engineering skills nor useful learning. What would take me 15 minutes to scrap together in a jupyter notebook takes me about an hour per their required solutions. There is also a written component to go with these gradescope portions, but all of the dependencies for those reports are required to be submitted in gradescope as well.

As others have said, the reports took an extreme amount of time to grade, there was little feedback if any on those, and there was no sharing of exam answers. As just one example, nearly all of the assignments prior to the drop deadline were not graded until only a few days before the drop deadline. You could have gone nearly the whole course making repeated mistakes without any of the instructors so much as giving you a hint. Because of the nature of the class (gradescope heavy) arbitrary mistakes could be costing you multiple letter grades on your assignments.

Overall, this was not much of a learning experience at all, and I think the course staff should be ashamed of their lack of dedication to the students' learning experience. Learning isn't a one-way street.

This course taught some interesting bits of stock investment. I came into this as your average index fund buy-holder (with some history in gambling with options). Concepts like mean-variance optimization and Sharpe ratio were enlightening. As was learning about technical trading and different investment strategies. 

The ML didn't go too deep but was enough to be interesting. We implemented regression trees, bag learners, and Q-Learning. I am taking reinforcement learning this semester, and the first few chapters of reading and the first lectures are very familiar from my experience in ML4T. 

During summer the last few weeks were quite busy. We had projects due back-back-back-back, and they were non-trivial.
  
My main complaint for the course is the project requirements were persnickety. You spend a lot of time and energy dealing with annoying requirements that don't facilitate learning, programming principles, or performance, but that help make the class easier to have at scale. 

Average course. Not really necessary to prepare for ML/RL. Don't regret taking, but also would've perhaps benefited more having taken something else.

Overall, I really liked it. It's a good course to review ML concepts through a trading/financial lens. I would say that the workload is more significant in the summer, though so keep that in mind if you are registering for a summer term.

I break down each assignment in greater detail on my Youtube video [here](https://youtu.be/nGlxczisZPI).

Machine Learning for Trading was a decent class. It was about the experience I expected, but there's room for improvement. For some background, I have about 5 years of professional programming experience, although most of it has been in test automation and modeling and simulation. The last year I've been working more in AI and autonomous systems, so I wanted to take some classes in ML. I am not all that interested in trading specifically, and I did not expect this course to be too difficult or dive very deep into machine learning, but I thought it might be a good intro to ML.

The course was slightly more challenging than I had anticipated, but most of that fell on 2 of the 8 projects, p3 (Assess Learners), and p8 (Strategy Evaluation). Those 2 were the only ones that took more than 6 hours. I have a lot of experience with vectorizing code in Python using Pandas and Numpy, so this course was probably easier for me than most. So It wasn't too bad IMO

Pros:
I felt like most of the projects had some value. There were a couple I could do without or would rather learn other things, but overall I felt like it was a decent workload and worthwhile projects.

Grading was pretty generous for the most part. Tests were closed book, closed note, multiple choice. I'm personally not a fan of closed tests like this, and I hate proctoring programs, but the tests weren't bad at all. They were 35 minutes, but I think I finished both in about 25 each. I also didn't do any of the textbook readings, but I did watch all the lectures, and got 23/25 on the midterm and 25/25 on the final. Honestly not sure how I pulled that off on the final but not complaining.

If you're interested in trading, there are some interesting concepts here. The actual programming for trading left a bit to be desired, but they were able to give a decent foundation for how it works and some things to look for. However, it was pretty basic, so it was nice for people like me who know nothing about trading, but might be too simple for people who already have an understanding.

Cons:
I have 3 complaints with this class, the complicated assignment descriptions, the outdated lectures, and lack of breadth in ML concepts.

Expect to spend 2-3 hours of your time figuring out the assignment and what exactly you're supposed to do. That might be a bit of an exaggeration in some cases, but that is actually how long it took me a couple times. The description itself is an entire essay, and there is still a large FAQ section on Ed Discussions with dozens of students having the same issues. There were multiple times I could tell that other students had the same misunderstandings that I did, but they were afraid to say exactly what the problem was because they were afraid of giving away too much information and violating the honor code or something.
